descriptionSet.description: The movie poster shows two different scenes of the movie "Zimbo", released in 1958, and directed by Homi Wadia. On the left side Azaad Irani, playing the role of Zimbo, can be seen carrying Chitra, playing the role of Leela Devi, in his arms. On the right side, Azaad Irani can be seen again with a group of animal such as tigers, chimpanzees and elephants.

inscription.text: Basant's ZIMBO Full Gevacolor Produced & directed by Homi Wadia - Music - Chitragupta Wadia Brothers Prod.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: Basant's ZIMBO Full Gevacolor Produced & directed by Homi Wadia - Music - Chitragupta Wadia Brothers Prod.
text-hi: ज़िम्बो

description-en: The movie poster shows two different scenes of the movie "Zimbo", released in 1958, and directed by Homi Wadia. On the left side Azaad Irani, playing the role of Zimbo, can be seen carrying Chitra, playing the role of Leela Devi, in his arms. On the right side, Azaad Irani can be seen again with a group of animal such as tigers, chimpanzees and elephants. (gs/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Story line of the movie: Professor Chakravarty has found the ultimate solution to aging through a chemical formula. Before he could experiment further on this, his dwelling in the jungles is attacked by a pride of lions, and he gets killed. His wife, Uma (Achala Sachdeo) loses her mind; and his 4 year old son is missing. Seventeen years later, the professor's brother and his daughter arrive there to search for the lost formula and the missing nephew, not knowing that the others accompanying them in this quest have an agenda of their own. cf. http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0390653/ (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: With Zimbo not wearing a shirt and showing off his muscles, the directors try to link the image of Zimbo with a lower class wrestler identity, that was predominant at that time in India. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Unlike the nationalist elite, the Wadias understood market forces and knew that popular passions would be the seeds for new modern Indian identities and that these could not be imposed from above. They recognised the potency of transcultural popular images and the hybrid fluidity of identities within the porous borders of a modern India in a transnational context. They ‘got’ the pleasures of Tarzan and Aladdin in a way that their elite critics did not, leaving them culturally and politically marginalised but ensuring them long-lasting enthusiasm from their loyal subaltern audiences. (Rosie Thomas)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The film ‘Indianised’ its sources, albeit in different ways. The ‘others’ of Zimbo/ Tarzan’s imaginary world were ‘tribal’ cannibals in an uncivilised jungle and seductively decadent ‘westernised’ babes swivelling their lipsticks. (Rosie Thomas)(gs)
related literature: Said, Edward 1995. "Orientalism". London: Penguin Books. (gs)
related hyperlinks: Thomas, Rosie 2010. "Still Magic. An Aladdin's Cave of 1950s B-Movie Fantasy" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/103/index.html, last accessed 2010-11-26. (gs)
